image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds his arms apart at a press conference in parliament house

items.synopsis: A No vote is recorded nationally and in at least five states as the Voice to Parliament proposal is defeated in Australia's first referendum this century. Follow all the results with our live blog.

title.children: PM says nation must seek a 'new way forward' after voters reject Voice to Parliament

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A fifth state has voted No. The ABC projects that Victoria has rejected the constitutional enshrinement of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. The referendum has already been defeated after failing to gain a majority of votes in a majority of states. It has also failed to gain a majority of voters nationally. Only Western Australia, where polls closed 31 minutes ago, remains in doubt.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ABC projection: Victoria has voted No on the Voice

children.content: A fifth state has voted No.
The ABC projects that Victoria has rejected the constitutional enshrinement of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.
The referendum has already been defeated after failing to gain a majority of votes in a majority of states.
It has also failed to gain a majority of voters nationally.
Only Western Australia, where polls closed 31 minutes ago, remains in doubt.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "My fellow Australians, the first time I spoke to you as prime minister of this nation, I repeated a commitment I had given many times before as Labor leader," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "I promised that our government would seek to implement the Uluru Statement from the Heart. "I gave my word to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leaders and elders who had poured their hopes and aspirations into that extraordinary statement. "I spoke to the people from all walks of life and all sides of politics, people of every faith and background and tradition, who had embraced this cause. "I promised our government would seek to answer the generous and gracious call of those 440 powerful words through a Voice, recognition, enshrined in the constitution. "I never imagined or indeed said that it would be easy. Very few things in public life worth doing are. "Nor could I guarantee the referendum would succeed. History told us that only eight out of 44 had done so. "What I could promise was that we would go all in, that we would try, and we have."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I promised we would go all in, and we have,' PM says

children.content: "My fellow Australians, the first time I spoke to you as prime minister of this nation, I repeated a commitment I had given many times before as Labor leader," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says.
"I promised that our government would seek to implement the Uluru Statement from the Heart.
"I gave my word to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leaders and elders who had poured their hopes and aspirations into that extraordinary statement.
"I spoke to the people from all walks of life and all sides of politics, people of every faith and background and tradition, who had embraced this cause.
"I promised our government would seek to answer the generous and gracious call of those 440 powerful words through a Voice, recognition, enshrined in the constitution.
"I never imagined or indeed said that it would be easy. Very few things in public life worth doing are.
"Nor could I guarantee the referendum would succeed. History told us that only eight out of 44 had done so.
"What I could promise was that we would go all in, that we would try, and we have."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister is speaking now. "My fellow Australians, at the outset, I want to say that while tonight's result is not one that I had hoped for, I absolutely respect the decision of the Australian people and the democratic process that has delivered it," Anthony Albanese says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM 'respects decision of the Australian people'

children.content: The prime minister is speaking now.

"My fellow Australians, at the outset, I want to say that while tonight's result is not one that I had hoped for, I absolutely respect the decision of the Australian people and the democratic process that has delivered it," Anthony Albanese says.

image.altText: A hand holds an Aboriginal flag in front of a large banner

items.synopsis: Australians have rejected recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the nation's first people in the constitution through the establishment of a Voice to Parliament advisory body.

title.children: Australians reject Indigenous recognition via Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, but the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly in inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: How did your electorate vote in the Voice referendum?

image.altText: The back of a woman with a vest saying Australian Official on it

items.synopsis: A flight for Australians to evacuate Israel has been cancelled, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has announced. Follow live.

title.children: Repatriation flights cancelled for Australians as Israel issues six-hour window for evacuations from Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestinian Health Ministry has reported 324 Palestinians have been killed and 1,000 injured in the past 24 hours. The death toll in the conflict has surpassed 3,500 on both sides and continues to soar. Since the conflict began last weekend at least 2,215 Palestinians have been killed and 8,714 wounded in Israeli air attacks on Gaza. Another 54 Palestinians were killed and 1,100 wounded in the West Bank according to the Health Ministry. In Israel the death toll has reached 1,300, with 3,400 wounded according to the Israeli Defense Force.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian Health Ministry reports 324 deaths in Gaza since yesterday

children.content: The Palestinian Health Ministry has reported 324 Palestinians have been killed and 1,000 injured in the past 24 hours.
The death toll in the conflict has surpassed 3,500 on both sides and continues to soar.
Since the conflict began last weekend at least 2,215 Palestinians have been killed and 8,714 wounded in Israeli air attacks on Gaza.
Another 54 Palestinians were killed and 1,100 wounded in the West Bank according to the Health Ministry.
In Israel the death toll has reached 1,300, with 3,400 wounded according to the Israeli Defense Force.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Smartraveller has just confirmed that Australian repatriation flights that were scheduled to leave Tel Aviv today will not depart. Here's the statement: The situation is highly challenging and rapidly changing. Unfortunately, we have been advised our scheduled flights will not depart Israel today. A further flight will not depart as scheduled tomorrow. The Australian government is working to ensure Australians who want to leave can do so as soon as possible. We will communicate to registered Australians about next available flights. Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories should register via https://crisis.dfat.gov.au/crisisportal/s/ or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian repatriation flights from Israel cancelled

children.content: Smartraveller has just confirmed that Australian repatriation flights that were scheduled to leave Tel Aviv today will not depart. Here's the statement:

The situation is highly challenging and rapidly changing. Unfortunately, we have been advised our scheduled flights will not depart Israel today. A further flight will not depart as scheduled tomorrow.
The Australian government is working to ensure Australians who want to leave can do so as soon as possible. We will communicate to registered Australians about next available flights.
Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories should register via
https://crisis.dfat.gov.au/crisisportal/s/
or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia will provide an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza. That will be split between $3 million through the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund "urgent needs like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict" and $7 million through United Nations agencies providing critical aid. The UN support will include emergency water supplies, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services and child protection. The Gaza Strip has been cut off from food, water and fuel supplies coming through Israel, with electricity also cut and several health facilities damaged in air strikes. "We have seen devastating loss of innocent life since the heinous attacks on Israel by brutal terrorist group Hamas," Foreign Minister Penny Wong said. "Far from representing the Palestinian people, Hamas undermines Palestinian needs and aspirations. "We continue to call for the unconditional release of all hostages. We stand with Israel and reiterate its right to defend itself. "President Biden has called on Israel to operate by the rules of war in its response to Hamas attacks — we join him and others in that call. "We call for safe and unimpeded humanitarian access to civilians affected by the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza. "We call for the establishment of a corridor to enable humanitarian needs to be met. And we support the work of the United States, Egypt and others towards this goal. "Adherence to international humanitarian law must be prioritised — including the protection of civilians, wherever they live."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia announces $10 million in aid for civilians in Gaza

children.content: Australia will provide an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza.
That will be split between $3 million through the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund "urgent needs
like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict" and $7 million through United Nations agencies providing critical aid.
The UN support will include emergency water supplies, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services and child protection.
The Gaza Strip has been cut off from food, water and fuel supplies coming through Israel, with electricity also cut and several health facilities damaged in air strikes.

props.alt: A girl sits next to containers as Palestinians gather to fill water from public taps amid the conflict with Israel in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, October 11, 2023.

children.content: People in Gaza have been filling water containers to get by.
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)
"We have seen devastating loss of innocent life since the heinous attacks on Israel by brutal terrorist group Hamas," Foreign Minister Penny Wong said.
"Far from representing the Palestinian people, Hamas undermines Palestinian needs and aspirations.
"We continue to call for the unconditional release of all hostages. We stand with Israel and reiterate its right to defend itself.
"President Biden has called on Israel to operate by the rules of war in its response to Hamas attacks — we join him and others in that call.
"We call for safe and unimpeded humanitarian access to civilians affected by the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
"We call for the establishment of a corridor to enable humanitarian needs to be met. And we support the work of the United States, Egypt and others towards this goal.
"Adherence to international humanitarian law must be prioritised — including the protection of civilians, wherever they live."
